what: Keep track of dates and medications through pregnancy and fertility treatment
title: Keep track of dates and medications through pregnancy and fertility treatment
text: work--progress R package calculating dates tracking medications pregnancy fertility treatment. extends private, personal package wrote pregnant, contains functions features found useful time, others added adapting package general use. R package latter stages development, view release mid-March 2025. main functionality now place. Still : improved documentation, vignette(s), better test coverage, improve messages utils functions.

title: Keep track of dates and medications through pregnancy and fertility treatment
text: can install development version pregnancy GitHub :
code: # install.packages("remotes")  remotes::install_github("EllaKaye/pregnancy")

title: Keep track of dates and medications through pregnancy and fertility treatment
code: library(pregnancy)

title: Keep track of dates and medications through pregnancy and fertility treatment
text: calculate_due_date() function estimates pregnancy due date. start_date interpreted differently, depending start_type. default, start_type last menstrual period, start_date date started. start_date options, like various transfer days, useful using IVF. due date know, how_far() function tells far pregnancy given date. defaults providing information current date, alternative on_date can provided. README built February 13, 2025, purposes reading page, counts “today”. date_when() function gives date certain week pregnancy () reached, duration date today: default, output messages second person, .e. addressed “”, also option specify another person. value 1 "" means ’ll addressed first person: character string interpreted third-person name, useful, example, ’re following pregnancy progress partner.
code: due_date <- calculate_due_date(as.Date("2024-12-10")) #> ℹ Estimated due date: Tuesday, September 16, 2025 #> ℹ Estimated birth period begins: August 26, 2025 (37 weeks) #> ℹ Estimated birth period ends: September 30, 2025 (42 weeks) how_far(due_date = due_date) #> ℹ You are 9 weeks and 2 days pregnant. #> ℹ That's 30 weeks and 5 days until the due date (September 16, 2025). #> ℹ You are 23% through the pregnancy. how_far(on_date = as.Date("2025-04-02"), due_date = due_date) #> ℹ On April 02, 2025, you will be 16 weeks and 1 day pregnant. date_when(28, due_date = due_date) #> ℹ On June 24, 2025, you will be 28 weeks pregnant. #> ℹ That's 18 weeks and 5 days away. how_far(due_date = due_date, person = 1) #> ℹ I am 9 weeks and 2 days pregnant. #> ℹ That's 30 weeks and 5 days until the due date (September 16, 2025). #> ℹ I am 23% through the pregnancy. date_when(6, due_date = due_date, person = "Ruth") #> ℹ On January 21, 2025, Ruth was 6 weeks pregnant. #> ℹ That was 3 weeks and 2 days ago.

title: Keep track of dates and medications through pregnancy and fertility treatment
text: tedious enter due date every time call how_far() date_when() course pregnancy, especially since date constant throughout. Similarly medications table medications_remaining(). avoid , pregnancy package makes use global options, can set set_* family functions, retrieved get_* family functions. global option can unset calling set_* function argument NULL.

title: Keep track of dates and medications through pregnancy and fertility treatment
text: can set pregnancy.due_date option using set_due_date() function. option set, due_date argument how_far() date_when() NULL (default), option retrieved. set_due_date() sets due date current R session. make option persist (recommended), can added .RProfile. console output set_due_date() provides guidance . how_far() can called without needing specify arguments, date_when() needs target week: check option set , use get_due_date().
code: set_due_date(due_date) #> ✔ Due date set as September 16, 2025 #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `due_date` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the `due_date` #>   argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `due_date` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.due_date = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `due_date`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `due_date` option with `get_due_date()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.due_date')`. how_far() #> ℹ You are 9 weeks and 2 days pregnant. #> ℹ That's 30 weeks and 5 days until the due date (September 16, 2025). #> ℹ You are 23% through the pregnancy.

title: Keep track of dates and medications through pregnancy and fertility treatment
text: set_person() sets global option pregnancy.person. option set retrieved specify value person how_far() date_when(), unless overriden passing another value directly person argument. option set, default second-person used.
code: set_person(1) #> ✔ person set as 'I' #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `person` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the `person` #>   argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `person` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.person = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `person`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `person` option with `get_person()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.person')`. how_far() #> ℹ I am 9 weeks and 2 days pregnant. #> ℹ That's 30 weeks and 5 days until the due date (September 16, 2025). #> ℹ I am 23% through the pregnancy. set_person(NULL) # TODO: update output to reflect that option has been unset #> ✔ person set as '' #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `person` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the `person` #>   argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `person` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.person = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `person`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `person` option with `get_person()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.person')`. how_far() #> ℹ You are 9 weeks and 2 days pregnant. #> ℹ That's 30 weeks and 5 days until the due date (September 16, 2025). #> ℹ You are 23% through the pregnancy.

what: Calculate estimated due date and birth period — calculate_due_date
title: Calculate estimated due date and birth period — calculate_due_date
text: Calculates estimated due date based start date type. function supports different start date types including last menstrual period (LMP), conception date, embryo transfer dates. also provides estimated birth period, spans 37 weeks (birth period start) 42 weeks (birth period end).

title: Calculate estimated due date and birth period — calculate_due_date
code: calculate_due_date(   start_date,   start_type = c("LMP", "conception", "transfer_day_3", "transfer_day_5",     "transfer_day_6"),   cycle = 28 )

title: Calculate estimated due date and birth period — calculate_due_date
text: start_date Date. starting reference date. interpretation date depends start_type parameter. start_type character. One : "LMP": Last Menstrual Period date (default) "conception": Date conception "transfer_day_3": Date day 3 embryo transfer "transfer_day_5": Date day 5 embryo transfer "transfer_day_6": Date day 6 embryo transfer cycle numeric. Length menstrual cycle days. used start_type = "LMP". Must 20 44 days. Defaults 28 days.

title: Calculate estimated due date and birth period — calculate_due_date
text: Returns Date object representing estimated due date invisibly. Also prints informative messages showing: estimated due date birth period begins (37 weeks) birth period ends (42 weeks)

title: Calculate estimated due date and birth period — calculate_due_date
text: due date calculated follows: LMP: Ovulation estimated start_date + cycle - 14 days, 266 days added conception: 266 days added conception date embryo transfers: appropriate number days subtracted get conception date (3, 5, 6 days), 266 days added birth period start date 21 days due date (37 weeks pregnant), birth period end date 14 days due date (42 weeks pregnant).

title: Calculate estimated due date and birth period — calculate_due_date
code: # Calculate due date from last menstrual period my_start_date <- as.Date("2023-01-31") calculate_due_date(my_start_date) #> ℹ Estimated due date: Tuesday, November 07, 2023 #> ℹ Estimated birth period begins: October 17, 2023 (37 weeks) #> ℹ Estimated birth period ends: November 21, 2023 (42 weeks)  # Calculate from conception date conception_date <- as.Date("2023-02-14") calculate_due_date(conception_date, start_type = "conception") #> ℹ Estimated due date: Tuesday, November 07, 2023 #> ℹ Estimated birth period begins: October 17, 2023 (37 weeks) #> ℹ Estimated birth period ends: November 21, 2023 (42 weeks)  # Calculate from day 5 embryo transfer transfer_date <- as.Date("2023-02-19") calculate_due_date(transfer_date, start_type = "transfer_day_5") #> ℹ Estimated due date: Tuesday, November 07, 2023 #> ℹ Estimated birth period begins: October 17, 2023 (37 weeks) #> ℹ Estimated birth period ends: November 21, 2023 (42 weeks)  # Calculate with non-standard cycle length calculate_due_date(my_start_date, cycle = 35) #> ℹ Estimated due date: Tuesday, November 14, 2023 #> ℹ Estimated birth period begins: October 24, 2023 (37 weeks) #> ℹ Estimated birth period ends: November 28, 2023 (42 weeks)

title: Calculate pregnancy test date — calculate_test_date
text: Calculates recommended date taking pregnancy test based start date type. function supports urine blood tests, blood tests typically viable 2 days earlier urine tests.

title: Calculate pregnancy test date — calculate_test_date
code: calculate_test_date(   start_date,   start_type = c("LMP", "conception", "transfer_day_3", "transfer_day_5",     "transfer_day_6"),   cycle = 28,   test_type = c("urine", "blood") )

title: Calculate pregnancy test date — calculate_test_date
text: start_date Date. starting reference date. interpretation date depends start_type parameter. start_type character. One : "LMP": Last Menstrual Period date (default) "conception": Date conception "transfer_day_3": Date day 3 embryo transfer "transfer_day_5": Date day 5 embryo transfer "transfer_day_6": Date day 6 embryo transfer cycle numeric. Length menstrual cycle days. used start_type = "LMP". Must 20 44 days. Defaults 28 days. test_type character. One : "urine": Home pregnancy test (default) "blood": Blood test clinic

title: Calculate pregnancy test date — calculate_test_date
text: Returns Date object invisibly representing recommended test date. Also prints informative messages showing: recommended date urine test recommended date blood test

title: Calculate pregnancy test date — calculate_test_date
text: test date calculated follows: First, ovulation date calculated (see calculate_due_date() details) urine tests: 14 days added ovulation date blood tests: 12 days added ovulation date Blood tests can typically detect pregnancy earlier urine tests due greater sensitivity detecting hCG hormone levels.

title: Calculate pregnancy test date — calculate_test_date
code: # Calculate test date from last menstrual period my_start_date <- as.Date("2023-01-31") calculate_test_date(my_start_date) #> ℹ Estimated test date (urine): Tuesday, February 28, 2023 #> ℹ Estimated test date (blood): Sunday, February 26, 2023  # Calculate for blood test from conception date conception_date <- as.Date("2023-02-14") calculate_test_date(conception_date,   start_type = "conception",   test_type = "blood" ) #> ℹ Estimated test date (urine): Tuesday, February 28, 2023 #> ℹ Estimated test date (blood): Sunday, February 26, 2023  # Calculate from day 5 embryo transfer transfer_date <- as.Date("2023-02-19") calculate_test_date(transfer_date,   start_type = "transfer_day_5" ) #> ℹ Estimated test date (urine): Tuesday, February 28, 2023 #> ℹ Estimated test date (blood): Sunday, February 26, 2023  # Calculate with non-standard cycle length calculate_test_date(my_start_date, cycle = 35) #> ℹ Estimated test date (urine): Tuesday, March 07, 2023 #> ℹ Estimated test date (blood): Sunday, March 05, 2023

what: Calculate and display date of specific pregnancy week — date_when
title: Calculate and display date of specific pregnancy week — date_when
text: Calculate display date specific pregnancy week

title: Calculate and display date of specific pregnancy week — date_when
code: date_when(weeks, due_date = NULL, person = NULL, today = Sys.Date())

title: Calculate and display date of specific pregnancy week — date_when
text: weeks Numeric value indicating number weeks pregnancy calculate date due_date Date. expected due date. NULL, try use "pregnancy.due_date" option. Required option set. person person pregnant, determine grammar output message. Can : "", "1", "1st", "first", numeric 1 first person "", "2", "2nd", "second", numeric 2 second person name third person NULL: try use "pregnancy.person" option. Defaults "" option set. today Date object representing reference date calculations. Default Sys.Date(). parameter exists primarily testing documentation purposes unlikely make sense user need want change default.

title: Calculate and display date of specific pregnancy week — date_when
text: Invisibly returns NULL. Prints messages console showing: specified week pregnancy occurs/occurred/occur far past/future date today (unless today date)

title: Calculate and display date of specific pregnancy week — date_when
text: function calculates someone /specific number weeks pregnant based due date. handles past, present future dates appropriately messaging. due date can provided directly set globally using options("pregnancy.due_date"). Similarly, person referenced can provided directly set globally using options("pregnancy.person").

title: Calculate and display date of specific pregnancy week — date_when
code: # Set a due date due <- as.Date("2024-09-01")  # When will they be 12 weeks pregnant? date_when(12, due_date = due) #> ℹ On February 18, 2024, you were 12 weeks pregnant. #> ℹ That was 51 weeks and 4 days ago.  # When will they be 20 weeks pregnant? date_when(20, due_date = due, person = "Sarah") #> ℹ On April 14, 2024, Sarah was 20 weeks pregnant. #> ℹ That was 43 weeks and 4 days ago.

what: Set or get the pregnancy.due_date option — due_date-option
title: Set or get the pregnancy.due_date option — due_date-option
text: Functions get set default due date used throughout package. affects calculations various functions determine pregnancy progress timing. Settings persist current R session , unless added .Rprofile. set_due_date() sets "pregnancy.due_date" option get_due_date() retrieves .

title: Set or get the pregnancy.due_date option — due_date-option
code: set_due_date(due_date)  get_due_date()

title: Set or get the pregnancy.due_date option — due_date-option
text: due_date Date object specifying estimated due date, NULL unset current value

title: Set or get the pregnancy.due_date option — due_date-option
text: functions invisibly return current due date setting: get_due_date() returns current setting (Date object) NULL set set_due_date() returns due date value set

title: Set or get the pregnancy.due_date option — due_date-option
code: # Store original setting original_due_date <- getOption("pregnancy.due_date")  # Check current setting get_due_date() #> ! You do not have `pregnancy.due_date` set as an option. #> ℹ You can set it by...  # Set due date using as.Date set_due_date(as.Date("2024-09-15")) #> ✔ Due date set as September 15, 2024 #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `due_date` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the `due_date` #>   argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `due_date` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.due_date = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `due_date`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `due_date` option with `get_due_date()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.due_date')`. get_due_date() #> ℹ Your due date is set as September 15, 2024.  # Set due date using lubridate library(lubridate) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘lubridate’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     date, intersect, setdiff, union set_due_date(ymd("2024-09-15")) #> ✔ Due date set as September 15, 2024 #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `due_date` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the `due_date` #>   argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `due_date` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.due_date = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `due_date`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `due_date` option with `get_due_date()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.due_date')`. get_due_date() #> ℹ Your due date is set as September 15, 2024.  # Restore original setting set_due_date(original_due_date) #> ✔ Due date set as NULL #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `due_date` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the `due_date` #>   argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `due_date` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.due_date = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `due_date`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `due_date` option with `get_due_date()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.due_date')`.

what: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
title: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
text: Calculates displays far along pregnancy specific date, including weeks pregnant, days remaining due date, overall progress percentage.

title: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
code: how_far(on_date = Sys.Date(), due_date = NULL, person = NULL)

title: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
text: on_date Date. date calculate pregnancy progress. Defaults current system date. due_date Date. expected due date. NULL, try use "pregnancy.due_date" option. Required option set. person person pregnant, determine grammar output message. Can : "", "1", "1st", "first", numeric 1 first person "", "2", "2nd", "second", numeric 2 second person name third person NULL: try use "pregnancy.person" option. Defaults "" option set.

title: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
text: Invisibly returns number days along pregnancy. Prints formatted message console pregnancy progress information.

title: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
text: function assumes standard pregnancy length 280 days (40 weeks) calculating progress. handles past, present, future dates appropriately adjusting message grammar. calculation shows 42 weeks pregnancy, different message displayed noting unusual duration. function uses cli package formatted message output supports proper pluralization weeks/days messages.

title: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
text: pregnancy.due_date: Date object setting default due date pregnancy.person: Character string setting default person

title: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
code: # Current progress with explicit due date # Note that output will depend on date the function is run how_far(due_date = as.Date("2025-07-01")) #> ℹ You are 20 weeks and 2 days pregnant. #> ℹ That's 19 weeks and 5 days until the due date (July 01, 2025). #> ℹ You are 51% through the pregnancy.  # Progress on a specific date how_far(   on_date = as.Date("2025-06-01"),   due_date = as.Date("2025-07-01") ) #> ℹ On June 01, 2025, you will be 35 weeks and 5 days pregnant.  # With custom person how_far(   on_date = as.Date("2025-06-01"),   due_date = as.Date("2025-07-01"),   person = "Sarah" ) #> ℹ On June 01, 2025, Sarah will be 35 weeks and 5 days pregnant.  # Set global options if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ set_due_date(as.Date("2025-07-01")) how_far() } # }

what: Set or Get the pregnancy.medications option — medications-option
title: Set or Get the pregnancy.medications option — medications-option
text: Functions get set default medications data frame used medications_remaining() function. Settings persist current R session , unless added .Rprofile. set_medications() sets "pregnancy.medications" option get_medications() retrieves .

title: Set or Get the pregnancy.medications option — medications-option
code: set_medications(medications)  get_medications()

title: Set or Get the pregnancy.medications option — medications-option
text: medications Data frame containing medication schedule. Must following columns: medication (character/factor): Name medication format (character/factor): Format medication (e.g., pill, injection) quantity (numeric): Number units take per day start_date (Date): Date start taking medication stop_date (Date): Final date medication taken NULL, try use "pregnancy.medications" option. Required option set.

title: Set or Get the pregnancy.medications option — medications-option
text: functions invisibly return current medications setting: get_medications() returns current setting (data frame) NULL set set_medications() returns medications data frame set

title: Set or Get the pregnancy.medications option — medications-option
code: # Store original setting original_medications <- getOption("pregnancy.medications")  # Set the option set_medications(pregnancy::medications) #> ✔ medications option set #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `medications` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the #>   `medications` argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `medications` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.medications = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `medications`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `medications` option with `get_medications()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.medications')`.  # Get the option get_medications() #> Your medications table is set as #> # A tibble: 14 × 5 #>    medication   format    quantity start_date stop_date  #>    <chr>        <chr>        <dbl> <date>     <date>     #>  1 progynova    tablet           3 2025-04-21 2025-04-30 #>  2 LDA          tablet           1 2025-04-21 2025-05-07 #>  3 prednisolone tablet           2 2025-04-26 2025-05-07 #>  4 progynova    tablet           6 2025-05-01 2025-07-11 #>  5 cyclogest    pessary          2 2025-05-03 2025-07-11 #>  6 lubion       injection        1 2025-05-03 2025-07-11 #>  7 clexane      injection        1 2025-05-08 2025-09-05 #>  8 prednisolone tablet           4 2025-05-08 2025-07-11 #>  9 prednisolone tablet           3 2025-07-12 2025-07-14 #> 10 prednisolone tablet           2 2025-07-15 2025-07-17 #> 11 prednisolone tablet           1 2025-07-18 2025-07-20 #> 12 prednisolone tablet           1 2025-07-22 2025-07-22 #> 13 prednisolone tablet           1 2025-07-24 2025-07-24 #> 14 prednisolone tablet           1 2025-07-26 2025-07-26  # Restore original setting set_medications(original_medications) #> ✔ medications option set #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `medications` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the #>   `medications` argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `medications` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.medications = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `medications`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `medications` option with `get_medications()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.medications')`.

title: An example medications table — medications

code: medications

text: data frame 14 rows 5 columns: medication Name medication format Format medication quantity Number taken per day start_date Date start taking medication stop_date Final date medication taken. See details.

what: Calculate remaining medications to be taken — medications_remaining
title: Calculate remaining medications to be taken — medications_remaining
text: Calculates displays many medications remain taken specific date, based schedule medications start stop dates. Results can grouped either medication name format (e.g., tablet, injection).

title: Calculate remaining medications to be taken — medications_remaining
code: medications_remaining(   medications = NULL,   group = c("medication", "format"),   on_date = Sys.Date(),   until_date = NULL )

title: Calculate remaining medications to be taken — medications_remaining
text: medications Data frame containing medication schedule. Must following columns: medication (character/factor): Name medication format (character/factor): Format medication (e.g., pill, injection) quantity (numeric): Number units take per day start_date (Date): Date start taking medication stop_date (Date): Final date medication taken NULL, try use "pregnancy.medications" option. Required option set. group Character string specifying group results. One : "medication": Group medication name (default) "format": Group medication format on_date Date object specifying date calculate remaining medications. Defaults current system date. until_date Date object specifying cut-date remaining medications. NULL, defaults latest stop_date medications

title: Calculate remaining medications to be taken — medications_remaining
text: Returns data frame containing remaining quantities, grouped specified. data frame two columns: First column: Either 'medication' 'format' depending grouping quantity_remaining: Total number units remaining medications remaining quantities > 0 included. medications remain, message printed console indicating , data frame 0 rows returned invisibly.

title: Calculate remaining medications to be taken — medications_remaining
text: pregnancy.medications: Data frame setting default medication schedule

title: Calculate remaining medications to be taken — medications_remaining
code: # Define medications table #' # Create example medication schedule meds <- data.frame(   medication = c("progynova", "prednisolone", "clexane"),   format = c("tablet", "tablet", "injection"),   quantity = c(3, 2, 1),   start_date = as.Date(c("2025-04-21", "2025-04-26", "2025-05-08")),   stop_date = as.Date(c("2025-04-30", "2025-05-07", "2025-09-05")) )  # Calculate remaining medications medications_remaining(   medications = meds,   on_date = as.Date("2025-04-21") ) #> # A tibble: 3 × 2 #>   medication   quantity_remaining #>   <chr>                     <int> #> 1 clexane                     121 #> 2 prednisolone                 24 #> 3 progynova                    30  medications_remaining(   medications = meds,   group = "format",   on_date = as.Date("2025-04-21") ) #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   format    quantity_remaining #>   <chr>                  <int> #> 1 injection                121 #> 2 tablet                    54  # Calculate medications in a given week medications_remaining(   medications = meds,   on_date = as.Date("2025-04-21"),   until_date = as.Date("2025-04-28") ) #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   medication   quantity_remaining #>   <chr>                     <int> #> 1 prednisolone                  6 #> 2 progynova                    24  # Set and use global medications option #' Store original medications setting original_medications <- getOption("pregnancy.medications") set_medications(pregnancy::medications) #> ✔ medications option set #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `medications` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the #>   `medications` argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `medications` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.medications = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `medications`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `medications` option with `get_medications()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.medications')`. medications_remaining(on_date = as.Date("2025-05-01")) #> # A tibble: 6 × 2 #>   medication   quantity_remaining #>   <chr>                     <int> #> 1 LDA                           7 #> 2 clexane                     121 #> 3 cyclogest                   140 #> 4 lubion                       70 #> 5 prednisolone                295 #> 6 progynova                   432  # Restore original medications setting set_medications(original_medications) #> ✔ medications option set #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `medications` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the #>   `medications` argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `medications` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.medications = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `medications`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `medications` option with `get_medications()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.medications')`.

what: Set or get the pregnancy.person option for pregnancy-related messages — person
title: Set or get the pregnancy.person option for pregnancy-related messages — person
text: Functions get set default person used messages throughout package. affects grammar pronouns used various function outputs. Settings persist current R session , unless added .Rprofile. set_person() sets "pregnancy.person" option get_person() retrieves .

title: Set or get the pregnancy.person option for pregnancy-related messages — person
code: set_person(person)  get_person()

title: Set or get the pregnancy.person option for pregnancy-related messages — person
text: person person pregnant, determine grammar output message. Can : "", "1", "1st", "first", numeric 1 first person "", "2", "2nd", "second", numeric 2 second person name third person NULL: try use "pregnancy.person" option. Defaults "" option set.

title: Set or get the pregnancy.person option for pregnancy-related messages — person
text: functions invisibly return current person setting: get_person() returns current setting (character string) NULL set set_person() returns person value set

title: Set or get the pregnancy.person option for pregnancy-related messages — person
code: # Store original setting original_person <- getOption("pregnancy.person")  # Check current setting get_person() #> ! You do not have `pregnancy.person` set as an option. #> ℹ You can set it by...  # Set to first person (using string) set_person("I") #> ✔ person set as 'I' #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `person` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the `person` #>   argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `person` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.person = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `person`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `person` option with `get_person()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.person')`. get_person() #> ℹ The person option is set as 'I'.  # Set to second person (using number) set_person(2) #> ✔ person set as 'You' #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `person` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the `person` #>   argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `person` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.person = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `person`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `person` option with `get_person()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.person')`. get_person() #> ℹ The person option is set as 'You'.  # Set to a specific name set_person("Sarah") #> ✔ person set as 'Sarah' #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `person` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the `person` #>   argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `person` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.person = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `person`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `person` option with `get_person()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.person')`. get_person() #> ℹ The person option is set as 'Sarah'.  # Restore original setting set_person(original_person) #> ✔ person set as '' #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `person` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the `person` #>   argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `person` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.person = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `person`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `person` option with `get_person()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.person')`.
